remarks: Modus tollendo ponens (inclusive-or version), aka disjunctive syllogism.  This is similar to ~ mtp-xor , one of the five original "indemonstrables" in Stoic logic.  However, in Stoic logic this rule used exclusive-or, while the name modus tollendo ponens often refers to a variant of the rule that uses inclusive-or instead.  The rule says, "if ` ph ` is not true, and ` ph ` or ` ps ` (or both) are true, then ` ps ` must be true."  An alternative phrasing is, "Once you eliminate the impossible, whatever remains, no matter how improbable, must be the truth." -- Sherlock Holmes (Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, 1890:  The Sign of the Four, ch. 6).  (Contributed by David A. Wheeler, 3-Jul-2016.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 11-Nov-2017.)
statement:
mtp-or.1 $e |- -. ph $.
mtp-or.2 $e |- ( ph \/ ps ) $.
mtp-or $p |- ps $.
